hints.content:
Two bars line up with $\blueD{12}$ on the scale.  


[[☃ image 1]]

There are $\blueD{12}$ alligators in each of those places.

options.alt: A bar graph shows the horizontal axis labeled Number of Alligators and the vertical axis labeled Place. The horizontal axis is labeled, from left to right: 0, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 15. The vertical axis is labeled from the bottom of the axis to the top of the axis as follows: Bite Swamp, Chomp Lake, Danger River, and Reptile Creek. The bar line for each place shows the following: Bite Swamp bar line extends to 12, Chomp Lake bar line extends to 6, Danger River bar line extends to 12, and Reptile Creek bar line extends to 9. A blue line is drawn up from 12, which reaches to the end of the Bite Swamp bar labeled 12 and to the end of the Danger River bar also labeled 12. Bite Swamp and Danger River bars are highlighted. !

hints.content: Bite Swamp and Danger River had the same number of alligators.

question.content:
James counted the number of alligators in various local bodies of water and graphed the results.


**Which bodies of water had the same number of alligators?**

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A bar graph shows the horizontal axis labeled Number of Alligators and the vertical axis labeled Place. The horizontal axis is labeled, from left to right: 0, 3, 6, 9, 12, and 15. The vertical axis is labeled from the bottom of the axis to the top of the axis as follows: Bite Swamp, Chomp Lake, Danger River, and Reptile Creek. The bar line for each place shows the following: Bite Swamp bar line extends to 12, Chomp Lake bar line extends to 6, Danger River bar line extends to 12, and Reptile Creek bar line extends to 9. !
